fr:mainmatter.fr:p: A category C consists of the following data:

fr:ul.fr:li: a collection of objects, overloadingly also called C;
for each pair of objects x,y\in C, a collection of morphisms C(x, y);
for each object x\in C, a designated identity morphism x\xrightarrow {1_x} x;
for each pair of morphisms x\xrightarrow {f} y\xrightarrow {g} z, a designated composite morphism x\xrightarrow {gf} z.

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: This data must satisfy the following axioms:

fr:ul.fr:li: unitality: for any x\xrightarrow {f} y, 1_yf = f = f1_x;
associativity: for any x\xrightarrow {f} y\xrightarrow {g}z\xrightarrow {h}w, h(gf) = (hg)f.

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: In other words, the following diagrams must commute:

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Category theory in context

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Suitable for advanced undergraduates and graduate students in mathematics, the text provides tools for understanding and attacking difficult problems in algebra, number theory, algebraic geometry, and algebraic topology. Drawing upon a broad range of mathematical examples from the categorical perspective, the author illustrates how the concepts and constructions of category theory arise from and illuminate more basic mathematical ideas. Prerequisites are limited to familiarity with some basic set theory and logic.
A category C consists of the following data:

fr:ul.fr:li: a collection of objects, overloadingly also called C;
for each pair of objects x,y\in C, a collection of morphisms C(x, y);
for each object x\in C, a designated identity morphism x\xrightarrow {1_x} x;
for each pair of morphisms x\xrightarrow {f} y\xrightarrow {g} z, a designated composite morphism x\xrightarrow {gf} z.

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: This data must satisfy the following axioms:

fr:ul.fr:li: unitality: for any x\xrightarrow {f} y, 1_yf = f = f1_x;
associativity: for any x\xrightarrow {f} y\xrightarrow {g}z\xrightarrow {h}w, h(gf) = (hg)f.

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: In other words, the following diagrams must commute:
Categories are ubiquitous in mathematics, as the following examples show.
The category of sets Set is the category whose objects are sets and whose morphisms are set-functions.
The category of relations Rel has sets as objects and relations as morphisms. Composition is given by existence, i.e. a (SR) c if and only if there is some b such that aRb and bRc.
The category of topological spaces Top is the category whose objects are topological spaces and whose morphisms are continuous functions.
We call these examples concrete. However, as the following examples show, not all categories look like this.
The empty category is the category with no objects and no morphisms.
The trivial category is the category with one object and only its identity morphism.

A preorder is a category P in which, for each pair of objects x and y, P(x, y) is either empty or a singleton. Explicitly, this means that it has a collection of elements (its objects) and a reflexive, transitive relation (inhabitance of hom-sets).
For any ordinal \alpha , there is a preorder whose objects are the smaller ordinals with the usual order.
A monoid can be thought of as a category with one object, whose morphisms are the elements of the monoid and whoses composition is the operation.
The category of groups Grp is the category whose objects are groups and whose morphisms are homomorphisms.

A relation in a category C on objects x and y is a monormorphism into the product x\times y; more generally, it consists of a pair of of jointly monic arrows r\xhookrightarrow {r_1} x, r\xhookrightarrow {r_2} y so that for any pair of parallel arrows z\xhookrightarrow {f, g} r, r_1g = r_1h and r_2g = r_2h implies g = h.
An elementary topos is a category which:

fr:ul.fr:li: is finitely complete and cocomplete;
is cartesian closed;
has a subobject classifier.

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: This is not a minimal definition; many of these pieces of structure imply each other.

fr:link.title: A leisurely introduction to simplicial sets

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let \Delta \xrightarrow {F} Cat send n in the abstract simplex to the ordinal category n. Then the nerve functor N is the right adjoint to the Kan extension of F to the category of simplicial sets. In particular, as n-simplices, FC has functors Fn\to C.

More concretely, let C be a small category. The nerve of C is the simplicial set whose n-simplicies are n-long strings of composable maps in C. The degeneracy map s_i takes a string of length n and inserts an identity at position i, while the face map d_i composes the ith and i+1st arrows (or else leaves out the first or last arrow, if i=0 or i=n.)

fr:link.title: A leisurely introduction to simplicial sets

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: The abstract simplex \Delta (also called the simplex category), is the category whose objects are the non-negative integers, thought of as finite ordinals, and whose morphisms are the non-decreasing functions between them.

The dense topology on a category C is the Grothendieck topology where a sieve S on x is covering if and only if, for every y\xrightarrow {f} x, there exists a z\xrightarrow {g} y such that the composite is in S.
A span in a category C is a diagram of shape \bullet \leftarrow \bullet \to \bullet . Dually, a cospan is a diagram of shape \bullet \to \bullet \leftarrow \bullet .
The trivial topology on a category C is the Grothendieck topology where the only covering sieve is the maximal sieve.

Equivalently, say that a sieve S covers a map y\xrightarrow {f} x if the
pullback f^*S covers y. Then the axioms state: 
if f\in  S, then S covers f;
  
if S covers f, then it covers fg for any g where the
  composition makes sense;
  
if S covers f and T covers each g\in  S, then T covers
  f.
A category equipped with a Grothendieck topology is called a site.
In the backwards direction, if J satisfies the map axioms, then letting f = 1_x shows that it satisfies the object axioms.
In the forwards direction, let J satisfy the object axioms. Then:

fr:ul.fr:li: For any sieve S on x and any f\in S, f^*S covers the domain of f by the stability axiom, so S covers f.
If S covers f, then f^*S covers the domain of f, so that by stability g^*f^*S covers the domain of g.

If S covers y\xrightarrow {f} x and T covers each g\in S, then f^*S covers the y, while for each g\in S, g^*T covers the domain of g. Now by transitivity, T covers x, so that by stability, T covers f.

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: It remains to show the desired adjunction. Since 1_y is terminal in C/y, a map n\to \Pi _f m in C/y induces, again by the universal property of the pullback, a unique map n\to \left [c\xrightarrow {m} x\xrightarrow {f} y^{(x\xrightarrow {f} y)}\right ] whose post-composition with m is the identity 1_f. Taking the transpose yields a map \left [f\times n\right ]\xrightarrow {g^\dag } \left [c\xrightarrow {m}x\xrightarrow {f} y\right ]. However, the product in C/y is exactly the pullback in C, so that (since mg = 1_x), this is equivalently a map f^*n\to m in C/x.
A least element or bottom \bot of a preorder P is an element such that \bot \leq x for all x\in P. The dual notion is greatest element or top \top .
Equivalently, considering P as a category, \bot is a terminal object and \top is a initial object.
A meet-pseudosemilattice is a poset with all binary meets. Dually, a join-pseudosemilattice is a poset with all binary joins.
Some authors use semilattice to refer to this notion, using (e.g.) bounded semilattice or semilattice with \top for what we call merely semilattice.
As a category, a meet-pseudosemilattice is a cartesian poset.

A meet, infimum, or greatest lower bound of a subset A\subseteq P in a preorder P is a greatest lower bound of A. We write \bigwedge {A}, or x\wedge y for \bigwedge \{x, y\}. The dual notion is join, supremum, or least upper bound, written \vee .
When P is considered as a category, a meet is a product and a join is a coproduct.
A category C is well-powered if all its subobject posets are small.

A preorder is a category P in which, for each pair of objects x and y, P(x, y) is either empty or a singleton. Explicitly, this means that it has a collection of elements (its objects) and a reflexive, transitive relation (inhabitance of hom-sets).
A category is skeletal if, whenever two objects are isomorphic, they are equal.
In a category with a zero object 0, the canonical morphism x\to 0\to y induced by the universal properties of initial and terminal objects is called the zero morphism 0_{x,y}.
Let C be a category. Then the following are equivalent:

fr:ul.fr:li: C is finitely complete;
C has a terminal object, binary products, and equalizers;
C has a terminal object and pullbacks.

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: The first immediately implies the next two, because they refer only to the existence of certain finite limits.
The second implies the first by the same construction as the proof of the completeness criterion, noticing there that if the indexing category J is finite, then so are each of the products.
A category is finite if it has only finitely many morphisms.

A functor C\xrightarrow {F} D is initial if for every category E and D-shaped diagram D\xrightarrow {K} E, there is a bijection which takes limit cones L\xrightarrow {\lambda _d} Kd to limit cones L\xrightarrow {\lambda _{Fc}} KFc.
Dually, a functor C\xrightarrow {F} D is final under the same condition about colimits.
A parallel pair is a pair of not-necessarily-equal morphisms x\overset {f,g}{\rightrightarrows } y. An opposing pair is a pair of morphisms f: x\rightleftarrows y: g.
In a category, the homsets C(x, y) are alternatively written \hom _C(x, y) and \operatorname {Hom}_C(x, y), sometimes with the subscript omitted.
A category J is filtered (\kappa -filtered) if every finite diagram (diagram with fewer than \kappa morphisms) has a cocone.

Let C\xrightarrow {K} D be a functor and E a category. Suppose that, for each C\xrightarrow {F} E, the left Kan extension D\xrightarrow {\operatorname *{Lan}_K} F exists. Then this data extends uniquely into a functor E^C \xrightarrow {\operatorname *{Lan}_K} E^D that is left adjoint to the precomposition functor E^D \xrightarrow {K^*} E^C.
Dually, if the right Kan extensions \operatorname *{Ran}_K F all exist, this extends into a right adjoint to K^*.

fr:tree.fr:mainmatter: By definition, Kan extensions are (co)free, and (co)free assignments extend uniquely to adjunctions.

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: A separator in a category C is an object s such that, for every parallel pair x\overset {f,g}{\rightrightarrows } y in C, if fe = ge for every s\xrightarrow {e} x, then f = g. A separating family is a collection of objects s_\alpha such that, if fe = ge for every \alpha and s_\alpha \xrightarrow {e} x, then f = g.

A subcategory of a category C is a collection of objects and morphisms from C closed under composition and containing all the identities. Following the pattern of subobjects, we identify a subcategory with the inclusion [functor] into C; in this sense, a subcategory is a faithful and injective on objects functor.
The Kleisli category C_T of a monad (T, \eta , \mu ) over a category C is the category with:

fr:ul.fr:li: objects those of C;
morphisms x\to y, written x\rightsquigarrow y the morphisms x\to Ty in C;
composition of x\overset {f}{\rightsquigarrow }y\overset {g}{\rightsquigarrow }z the composite x\xrightarrow {f}Ty\xrightarrow {Tg}T^2z\xrightarrow {\mu _z} Tz in C;
identities x\overset {1_x}{\rightsquigarrow } x the units x\xrightarrow {\eta _x} Tx of T.

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: (Associativity and unitality follow from the monad laws.)
The Eilenberg-Moore category C^T of a monad T is the category whose objects are T-algebras and whose morphisms are algebra homomorphisms.

Let (T, \eta , \mu ) be monad on a category C. Then the category of resolutions of T \operatorname *{Adj}_T has as objects resolutions of T, and as morphisms morphisms of adjunctions whose action on C is by the identity; note that the additional compatibility condition 1_C\eta = \eta 1_C from the definition of morphism of adjunction is satisfied by construction, because both adjunctions have the same unit.

Let (T, \eta , \mu ) be a monad on a category C and x\in C an object. Then the free algebra on x is the map T^2x\xrightarrow {\mu _x} Tx. The free algebra functor C\xrightarrow {F^T} C^T from C to the Eilenberg-Moore category of T takes a map x\xrightarrow {f} y to the homomorphism Tx\xrightarrow {Tf} Tb.
Let T be a monad on a category C. A resolution of T is an adjunction which induces T.
An endofunctor is an endomorphic functor, i.e. a functor whose domain and codomain agree. The endofunctor category over a category C is the functor category C^C.
A monad on a category C is a monoid in the endofunctor category C^C. Explicitly, this consists of:

fr:ul.fr:li: an endofunctor C \xrightarrow {T} C;
a unit natural transformation 1_C\xrightarrow {\eta } T from the identity functor;
a multiplication natural transformation T^2\xrightarrow {\mu } T.

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Because the monoidal structure of the endofunctor category is strict, the monoid laws take the form of commutativity of the following diagrams of whiskered composites:
Let J be an index category and let C be J-complete. Then there is a functor C^J \xrightarrow {\operatorname *{lim}_J} C which acts on functors by taking the limit.
Note that this theorem relies on a choice of witnesses to the completeness of C, i.e. a canonical choice of limit of each J-shaped diagram.
Cat is the category of locally small categories.
A category is complete if and only if it has all small products and equalizers.
Dually, a category is cocomplete if and only if it has all small coproducts and coequalizers.
The forwards direction is immediate, because products and equalizers are limits.
In the backwards direction, let J\xrightarrow {F} C be a small diagram. Now we define maps c and d using the universal property of the product as follows:

To demonstrate the universal property of the limit, let z\xrightarrow {\mu } F be another cone over F. Then the legs of the cone yield a map z\to \prod _{j\in J} Fj by the universal property of the product. Since it is a cone, hence commutes with Ff, this map equalizes the previous diagram. We obtain the desired result by the universal property of the equalizer.
A category C is locally small if for each pair of objects x and y, the collection C(x, y) forms a set.
A category is connected if any pair of objects are connected by a zig-zag.
A zig-zag in a category is a finite diagram of shape \bullet \leftarrow \bullet \to \bullet \leftarrow \bullet \to \bullet \dots \bullet \leftarrow \bullet \to \bullet .
A category is cocomplete if it has all small colimits.
A category is complete if it has all small limits.

Let c be an object in a category C, and let J be any category. The constant functor at c is the functor J\xrightarrow {c} C that sends every object of J to c and every morphism of J to the identity 1_c.

The constant functors induce a functor C\xrightarrow {\Delta } J^C to the functor category which sends each object of C to the corresponding constant functor and each morphism x\xrightarrow {f}y to the natural transformation with components \alpha _j = f for each j\in J.
A commutatitive diagram in a category C is a functor J\xrightarrow {D} C. The domain J is called the indexing category or the shape of the diagram.
A category is small if its collection of morphisms forms a set.

fr:title.text: Terminal object › universal property of terminal objects

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Terminal object › universal property of terminal objects

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: By the universal property of limits, an object t is terminal in the category C if and only if for every object c, there is a unique morphism c\to t.

fr:title.text: Initial object › universal property of initial objects

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Initial object › universal property of initial objects

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: By the universal property of colimits, an object i is initial in the category C if and only if for every object c, there is a unique morphism i\to c.
A concrete category is a category C equipped with a forgetful functor C\xrightarrow {U} Set.
A morphism creates a property if it reflects and preserves that property and if, whenever the property obtains in the codomain, it is in the image of the morphism.
A discrete category is a category with no non-identity morphisms.
The empty category is the ordinal category 0. Explicitly, it is the category with no objects and no morphisms.
A monoid can be thought of as a category with one object, whose morphisms are the elements of the monoid and whoses composition is the operation.
A morphism preserves a property if, whenever the property obtains in its domain, it obtains in its codomain.
A presheaf on a category C is a contravariant functor C^\text {op}\to Set. The presheaf category \hat {C} is the functor category Set^{C^\text {op}} of presheaves on C.
A morphism reflects a property if, whenever the property obtains in its codomain, it obtains in its domain.
Let x and y be objects in a category C. Then the following are equivalent:

fr:ul.fr:li: x and y are isomorphic;
the covariant hom-functors C(x, -) and C(y, -) are naturally isomorphic;
the contravariant hom-functors C(-, x) and C(-, y) are naturally isomorphic.

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Furthermore, by the Yoneda embedding, a choice of any such isomorphism canonically determines a choice of each of the others.
This is immediate from the Yoneda lemma, since fully faithful functors create isomorphism.
We prove the covariant case. The forwards result comes from functoriality of the Yoneda embedding and the fact that functors preserve isomorphism.

In the backward direction, let \eta : C(x, -)\to C(y, -) be a natural isomorphism. Define t = \eta _x(1_x), which is a morphism y\to x, and u = \eta _y^{-1}(1_y), which is a morphism x\to y. We claim these are inverses.
The trivial category is the ordinal category 1. Explicitly, it is the category with one object and no non-identity morphisms.

Let c and d be objects in a category C, and suppose that F and x express universal properties of both c and d. Then there is a canonical isomorphism c\cong d; in particular, a unique isomorphism that commutes with the corresponding representations.
We are thus justified in referring to "the universal object with an x."

Let C(c, -)\overset {\alpha _x}{\cong } F and C(d, -)\overset {\beta _x}{\cong } F be the corresponding natural isomorphisms given by definition of a universal property. Then their composition gives an isomorphism C(c, -)\cong C(d, -), which lifts to an isomorphism c\cong d by the Yoneda lemma.
The category of sets Set is the category whose objects are sets and whose morphisms are set-functions.
The category of topological spaces Top is the category whose objects are topological spaces and whose morphisms are continuous functions.
A contravariant functor between categories C and D is a functor F: C^\text {op}\to D.

Let c be an object in a category C. The contravariant hom-functor C^\text {op}\xrightarrow {C(-, c)} Set takes an object x to the hom-set C(x, c) and a morphism x\xrightarrow {f} y to its action f^* by pre-composition:
This functor is also called the presheaf represented by c, and is written yc, y^c or h^c, the former two in reference to the Yoneda embedding.

Let c be an object in a category C. The covariant hom-functor C\xrightarrow {C(c, -)} Set takes an object x to the hom-set C(c, x) and a morphism x\xrightarrow {f} y to its action f_* by post-composition:
This functor is also called the functor represented by c, and is written y_c or h_c, the first in reference to the Yoneda embedding.
A morphism x\xtwoheadrightarrow {f} y is an epimorphism if for any pair of parallel arrows y\overset {g,h}{\rightrightarrows } z, gf = hf implies g = h.
A functor C\xrightarrow {F} D between categories C and D consists of the following data:

fr:ul.fr:li: for each object x\in C, an object Fx\in D;
for each morphism f\in C(x, y), a morphism Ff\in D(Fx, Fy).

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: This data must preserve the structure of the category, namely identities and composites, meaning:

fr:ul.fr:li: for each object x\in C, F1_x = 1_{Fx};
for each pair x\xrightarrow {f}y\xrightarrow {g}z in C, F(gf) = (Fg)(Fg).

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let C and D be categories. The functor category D^C has:

fr:ul.fr:li: as objects, functors C\to D;
as morphisms, natural transformations;
as composition, vertical composition;
as identities, the identity natural transformations.

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: A groupoid is a category whose morphisms are each isomorphisms.

Let C be a category. The hom bifunctor C^\text {op}\times C\xrightarrow {C(-, -)} Set takes objects x and y to the hom-set C(x, y), and morphisms x\xleftarrow {f} y and z\xrightarrow {g} w to their action by pre- and post-composition f^*g_*, i.e.
Let C be a category. The identity functor C\xrightarrow {1_C}C sends each object and morphism to itself.
A morphism x\xhookrightarrow {f} y is a monomorphism if for any pair of parallel arrows z\overset {g,h}{\rightrightarrows } x, fg = fh implies g = h.
The product category is the product in Cat. Explicitly, let C and D be categories. The product category C\times D has:

fr:ul.fr:li: as objects, pairs (x, y) of objects in C and D, respectively;
as morphisms (x, y)\to (x', y'), pairs (f, g) of morphisms x\xrightarrow {f} x' and y\xrightarrow {g} y';
composition and identities defined componentwise.

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: A morphism y\xrightarrow {r}x is a retraction, post-inverse, or split epimorphism if there exists a morphism x\xrightarrow {s}y such that rs = 1_x.
A morphism x\xrightarrow {s}y is a section, pre-inverse, or split monomorphism if there exists a morphism y\xrightarrow {r}x such that rs = 1_x.
Let C be a category and c be an object. Then the coslice category or under category c/C is:

fr:ul.fr:li: the category of elements of the covariant hom-functor C(c, -);
the comma category (c\downarrow 1_C), where *\xrightarrow {c} C is the inclusion of the point.

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Explicitly, it has:

fr:ul.fr:li: as objects, morphisms c\xrightarrow {f} x in C;
as composition, pasting along the shared morphism;
as identities, the unit laws in C.

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: A morphism in a category is an endomorphism if its domain and codomain agree.
A morphism x\xrightarrow {f} y in a category is an isomorphism if there exists an inverse morphism y\xrightarrow {f^{-1}}x such that f^{-1}f = 1_x and ff^{-1} = 1_y, i.e.
and
commute. If there exists an isomorphism between x and y, we say they are isomorphic and write x\cong y.
Let C be a category. The opposite category C^{\text {op}} has:

fr:ul.fr:li: the same objects as in C;
for each morphism x\xrightarrow {f} y in C, a morphism y\xrightarrow {f^{\text {op}}} x;
composition and identities as in C.

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let C be a category and c be an object. Then the slice category or over category C/c is:

fr:ul.fr:li: the category of elements of the contravariant hom-functor C(-, c);
the comma category (1_C\downarrow c), where *\xrightarrow {c} C is the inclusion of the point.

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Explicitly it has:

fr:ul.fr:li: as objects, morphisms x\xrightarrow {f} c in C;
as composition, pasting along the shared morphism;
as identities, the unit laws in C.

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: An adjunction F \dashv G between categories C and D entails the following data:

fr:ul.fr:li: a pair of functors F:C\leftrightarrows D:G, called the left and right adjoints;
a family of natural bijections D(Fc, d)\cong C(c, Gd), called transposition;
a natural transformation 1_C\xrightarrow {\eta } GF, called the unit;
a natural transformation FG\xrightarrow {\epsilon } 1_D, called the counit.

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: This data relates as follows:

fr:ul.fr:li: the component c\xrightarrow {\eta _c}GFc of the unit is the transpose of the identity 1_{Fc};
the component FGd\xrightarrow {\epsilon _d}d of the counit is the transpose of the identity 1_{Gd};
the transposition of a map Fc\xrightarrow {f} d is the composite c\xrightarrow {\eta _c} GFc\xrightarrow {Gf} Gd;
the transposition of a map c\xrightarrow {g} Gd is the composite Fc\xrightarrow {Fg} FGd\xrightarrow {\epsilon _d} d;

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let F: C\leftrightarrows D: G be a pair of opposing functors. Then the following are equivalent specifications of an adjunction:

fr:ul.fr:li: there exists a natural bijection D(Fc, d)\cong C(c, Gd);
there exists a pair of natural transformations 1_C\xrightarrow {\eta } GF and FG\xrightarrow {\epsilon } 1_D satisfying the triangle identities;

there exists a natural transformation FG\xrightarrow {\epsilon } 1_D so that the formula for adjoint maps induces an isomorphism (-)^\sharp = C(c, Gd)\xrightarrow {F} D(Fc, FGd)\xrightarrow {(\epsilon _d)_*} D(Fc, d).

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: The first implies the second via the triangle identities of the unit and counit.

fr:ul.fr:li: H\eta = \eta 'H, where \eta and \eta ' are the units of the adjunctions;
K\epsilon = \epsilon 'K, where \epsilon and \epsilon ' are the counits of the adjunctions;
transposition commutes with H and K.

fr:title.text: A square commutes iff its adjoint does

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: A square commutes iff its adjoint does

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: In the forwards direction, suppose that the isomorphisms are natural, and further that the left-hand square commutes; the case in which the right-hand square commutes is similar. By the naturality of the isomorphism in C, the transpose of kf^\sharp is (Gk) f^\flat , while by naturality in D, the transpose of (Fh)g^\sharp is hg^\flat . Since the maps are equal, their transposes must also be equal; this is commutativity of the square on the right.

fr:title.text: Adjoints are unique up to unique isomorphism

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Adjoints are unique up to unique isomorphism

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let F and F' be left adjoints to G. Then there is a unique natural isomorphism \theta : F\cong F' commuting with the units and counits of the adjunctions.
Dually, right adjoints are also unique up to unique isomorphism commuting with the units and counits.
To show uniqueness, note that \theta _c is uniquely specified as the transpose of \eta '_c across the adjunction F\dashv G, but this relationship is required for commutativity with the units to hold.
There are composite bijections of hom-sets E(F'Fc, e)\cong D(Fc, G'E)\cong C(c, GG'e).

Let \eta and \epsilon be the unit and counits of the adjunction F\dashv G. We give a unit \eta ' and counit \epsilon ' witnessing the adjunction F_*\dashv G_*. Given a functor J\xrightarrow {H} C, the component H\xrightarrow {\eta '_H} GFH is the whiskered natural transformation \eta H. Given a functor J\xrightarrow {K} D, the component FGK\xrightarrow {\epsilon '_K} K is similarly \epsilon K.

Let C\xrightarrow {F} D be a functor so that, for each object d\in D, there exists a cofree object Gd\in C, i.e. an object Gd\in C together with an isomorphism {D(Fc, d)\cong C(c, Gd)} natural in D. Then there exists a unique extension of this assignment into a functor D\xrightarrow {G} C, which is then necessarily right adjoint to F.
Dually, suppose that for each d\in D, there exists a free object Fd\in C. Then this data extends uniquely into a functor D\xrightarrow {G} C which is necessarily left adjoint to F.

fr:title.text: Properties of adjoint functors relate to those of their (co)units

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Properties of adjoint functors relate to those of their (co)units

fr:title.text: Right adjoints preserve limits; left adjoints preserve colimits

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Right adjoints preserve limits; left adjoints preserve colimits

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Right adjoints preserve limits. Dually, left adjoints preserve colimits.

Letting \Delta be the constant diagram functor, we have the following series of natural isomorphisms: \begin {aligned} C^J(\Delta c, GK) &\cong D^J(F\Delta c, K) &&\text {by (1)}\\\\ &\cong D^J(\Delta Fc, K) &&\text {by (2)}\\\\ &\cong D(Fc, \operatorname *{lim}_J K) &&\text {by the definition of limits}\\\\ &\cong C(c, G\operatorname *{lim}_J K) &&\text {by the adjunction}. \end {aligned} By definition of limits, this exhibits G\operatorname *{lim}_J K as a limit of GK.

Let D\xrightarrow {G} C be a continuous functor with locally small complete domain D. Suppose that D satisfies the solution set condition: for each object c in C, there exists a small family of maps c\xrightarrow {f_i} Gd_i in C such that any map c\xrightarrow {f} Gd factors through one of the f_i via the G-image of a map d_i\to d in D. Then G admits a left adjoint.

Let D\xrightarrow {G} C be a continuous functor with complete domain and locally small domain and codomain. Suppose that D has a small coseparating family and that every collection of subobjects x_\alpha \hookrightarrow x in D admits a meet, i.e. a limit. Then G has a left adjoint.
A poset is a preorder which is skeletal as a category; equivalently, this means its relation is additionally antisymmetric.
A binary operation on X is associative if, for all a, b, c\in X, (ab)c = a(bc).
A (two-sided) identity for a binary operation on X is an element e\in X such that for all x\in X, ex = xe = x. If only one identity holds, this is a left- or right-identity, as appropriate.
